newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian gold ends steady, silver falls.
newsitem.headline: Indian gold ends steady, silver falls.

text.p: Gold 24 carat closes 5.0 rupees higher at 4,850 per 10 grammes moving in a narrow band on limited seasonal buying and reduced arrivals of imported gold from the Gulf due to the Moslem festival of Eid al-Adha.
** Prices of gold biscuits (116.50 grammes) close steady at 56,700 rupees per piece in limited early trade. Biscuits gained 200 rupees on Thursday.
** Silver .999 opens 30 rupees lower at 6,970 per kg on a weak world trend and falls further by another 30 rupees by close. It gained 20 rupees on Thursday.
Gold 24 carats opened 5.0 rupees higher at 4,850 rupees per 10 grammes on stray seasonal buying but stayed in a narrow band to close at the same level. Arrivals were low.
Arrivals of gold from Gulf countries dropped due to the Moslem festival of Eid al-Adha.
Dealers estimated the arrival of imported gold at 100 kgs on Friday against the normal average of 400-500 kgs.
"The trend is weak as supplies are expected to rise in the next few days. The present rise is temporary," said a dealer. Gold was up 15 rupees per 10 grammes on Thursday.
Prices of gold biscuits were steady in early trade at 56,700 rupees per piece after gaining 200 rupees on Thursday.

Silver .999 opened 30 rupees lower at 6,970 rupees per kg on a downtrend in the world market and fell further by a similar amount by close. Industrial buying was sluggish. Silver was up 20 rupees per kg on Thursday.
Dealers said they would expect gold supplies to rise in the next week with the return of Indian haj pilgrims who normally buy some gold during their vist to Saudi Arabia.
They said arrivals of imported silver too would improve because the downtrend in the world market. (Conversion $1=35.79 rupees)
